thread.title_full: Bill Shorten attacks continue in parliament

author: Malcolm Farr
title: Bill Shorten attacks continue in parliament
text:
THE Government today again launched a savage personal attack on Bill Shorten after a poll indicated its previous character assault had wounded the Opposition Leader. 
Defence Industry Minister Christopher Pyne came close to accusing Mr Shorten of a form of corruption as he foreshadowed Government legislation based on findings of the Trade Union Royal Commission.
Mr Shorten has consistently denied any wrongdoing, and after a lengthy appearance by him, the royal commission made no adverse findings against him.
Mr Pyne repeated to Parliament the well-known story of how Mr Shorten and his then wife Debbie Beale had a South American holiday with packaging billionaire Richard Pratt and family.
Mr Pyne was elaborating on a theme raised last week by Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull who accused Mr Shorten of social climbing.
Today there was a sharper edge as Mr Pyne referred to “union leaders that receive thousands in personal benefits from employers, with whom they are negotiating” on behalf of members.
He foreshadowed legislation to deal with such union leaders who were “clearly placing themselves in a position of conflict of interest”.
“Imagine if a union leader travelled with a billionaire, who owned a jet, with their family to Easter Island, Argentina and Cuba and, at the same time (was about) to sign an enterprise business agreement that took away the maternity leave rights of the workers who worked
for that particular business, and required that all the workers’ super got paid into that business’ super fund?” said Mr Pyne.
“Now, it wouldn’t happen. Nobody could imagine it, could they?
“But it might ring a bell to one person in this House. It’s our old China (plate) over here, the Leader of the Opposition.
Minister for Defence Industry Christopher Pyne didn’t hold back. Picture: Mick Tsikas Source: AAP 
“Because that’s exactly what the Leader of the Opposition did when he was the AWU secretary.
“He travelled with the Pratt family, who owned Visy Industries, to Cuba, to Argentina, to Easter Island, and signed, as the national secretary of the AWU, an agreement with Visy Industries that removed the maternity leave rights and turned them into unpaid maternity leave for the workers of Visy Industries and required the workers’ super get paid into the Pratt super fund.
“Now, we are going to make that illegal.”
The Government could have been encouraged to renew the personal attack by an Essential poll which today reported Mr Shorten’s approval rating had fall from 37 per cent in January to 30 per cent now, four weeks later.
Mr Pyne continued with a reference to Labor Senator Kimberley Kitching — another union identity who was prominent in the TURC, and whom Mr Shorten sponsored into her Upper House position.
“Amazingly, he took now-Senator Kimberley Kitching and her husband, Andrew Landeryou, on that trip,” he told Parliament.
“You can just imagine them at the Plaza de Mail, the Presidential Palace, smoking Cuban cigars, Senator Kitching doing her best impersonation of Don’t Cry For Me, Argentina , over the balcony to the bemused tourists wondering what was going on.
“The thing about the Labor Party and this particular Leader of the Opposition, he’s not much unlike Eva Peron (the legendary Argentinian First Lady of the early 1950s) pretending to be the workers’ friends while actually selling them down the river.
“Look at what he does, never what he says.”
